facts.text: Sessions Judge of Indore acquitted all seven accused charged with murder of Sobal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge of Indore ac- quitted all the seven accused who were charged with the murder of one Sobal Singh.

facts.text: High Court maintained acquittal of five accused (Jinnatbai, Gaburia, Ismail, Sardar, Bashir) but reversed for Sohrab and Nadar.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal by the State, the High Court while maintaining the acquittal of five of them viz. Jinnatbai, Gaburia, Ismail, Sardar and Bashir reversed it in respect of Sohrab and Nadar

facts.text: High Court convicted Sohrab and Nadar under Section 302/34 IPC and sentenced each to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: , whom he companyvicted under Section 302/34 and sentenced each of them to life imprisonment. They were also companyvicted under Section 25-A of the Arms Act

facts.text: Strained relationship between accused and deceased due to murder of Kudrat (husband of Jinnatbai) in December 1963, where Sobal Singh was prosecuted but acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that there was a strained relationship between the accused and the deceased inasmuch as in December, 1963, one Kudrat, the husband of Jinnatbai, was murdered and for that murder, Sobal Singh, the deceased, was prosecuted along with another person, but they were acquitted.

facts.text: On morning of 26th February 1966, seven accused started from house of Sohrab.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that on the morning of 26th February, 1966 all the seven accused started from the house of Sohrab.

facts.text: Jinnatbai with her little son and Nadar went in a chhakda driven by Gaburia; Ismail, Bashir and Sardar on bicycles; Sohrab riding a mare carrying unlicensed revolver.

anchor.surface_text: Jinnatbai with her little son and Nadar went in a chhakda driven by Gaburia. Ismail, Bashir and Sardar were on bicycles and Sohrab was riding a mare and was carrying unlicensed-revolver with him.

facts.text: Jinnatbai handed unlicensed gun to Nadar which he kept in the Chhakda.

anchor.surface_text: At the time when they left, it also appears that Jinnatbai handed to Nadar an unlicensed gun which he kept in the Chhakda.

facts.text: Sobal Singh left Solsindhi for Sanwer on foot accompanied by Chhogia, followed by Madhosingh, Kishandas, Kana and Bhawarsingh in a Chhakda.

anchor.surface_text: It is further alleged that shortly before the departure of the accused persons, Sobal singh left Solsindhi for Sanwer on foot accompanied by one Chhogia and were closely followed by Madhosingh, Kishandas, Kana and Bhawarsingh in a Chhakda.

facts.text: Near village Maharajganj, accused overtook the two groups and went ahead; Sohrab turned mare round and chased Sobal Singh across fields in mouza Ranwer.

anchor.surface_text: Near the village Maharajganj, the, accused persons were alleged to have overtaken the two groups of persons and went further ahead. Then Sohrab turned his mare round and began to chase Sobalsingh across the fields which lie within the boundaries of mouza Ranwer.

facts.text: Sohrab fired revolver at Sobal Singh several times, caught him by shirt which came off.

anchor.surface_text: Chofia however ran away. It is the prosecution case that in the companyrse of the chase Sohrab fired at Sobals ingh several times with his revolver and at one point caught him by the shirt which came off.

facts.text: Nadar came running with double-barrelled shot-gun, handed to Sohrab, caught hold of Sobal Singh; Sohrab fired gun, both Sobal Singh and Nadar fell.

anchor.surface_text: Sohrab threw away that shirt and companytinued to chase the deceased a little farther after which he dismounted the mare. Just then Nadar came running with a double-barrelled shot-gun, which he handed to Sohrab and caught hold of Sobalsingh. Sohrab is then alleged to have fired the gun at Sobalsingh as a result of which both Sobalsingh and Nadar fell down.

facts.text: Sohrab fired again at Sobal Singh lying on ground face up; Bashir and Sardar came and struck with knives.

anchor.surface_text: Nadar, however, got up and thereafter Sohrab again fired at Sobalsingh who was lying on the ground, face up. Just at that time Bashir and Sardar came running to the spot and struck Sobalsingh with knives.

facts.text: Sobal Singh died on spot due to firing by Sohrab and stabbing by Bashir and Sardar.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that as a result of the cumulative effect of firing by Sohrab and stabbing by Bashir and Sardar, Sobalsingh died on the spot

facts.text: Within an hour, deceased's father Madhosingh (eye witness) made report at police station Sanwar, 1.5 miles from scene; FIR issued.

anchor.surface_text: , after which Sohrab, Nadar, Bashir and Sardar went upto the Chhakda, and on Jinnatbai asking whether the man was dead or alive, she was told that he had been finished and Kudarat avenged. Within an hour of the incident, the deceaseds father, Madhosingh, who himself claims to be an eye witness, made a report at the police station, Sanwar, which is only a mile and a half from the scene of the occurrence. After recording the information an F.I.R. was issued.

facts.text: Police seized articles from spot: used/unused ammunition, shirt, stirrup with strap.

anchor.surface_text: The police reached the spot where the body of Sobalsingh was lying and from that place and the- fields in the vicinity, seized several articles including used and unused ammunition of shotgun and revolver, a shirt- and a stirrup with a piece of its strap which was detached from the saddle

facts.text: After arrest based on Bashir's statement, two knives recovered from trunk of date palm tree near Bhaori and Deorakhedi.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that after the accused persons were arrested as a result of the statement made by- Bashir two knives were recovered from the trunk of a date palm tree near the border of villages Bhaori and Deorakhedi

facts.text: Sohrab pointed out place where he broke revolver and gun, burnt wooden components; firearm parts recovered.

anchor.surface_text: Sohrab is said to have pointed out a, place also on the border of those villages, as the place where he is alleged to have broken up the revolver and the, gun and cut up and burnt the wooden companyponents of the gun. As a companysequence of this statement,. several articles companynected with the firearm Were recovered.

facts.text: Divers recovered disjointed firearm parts and cartridges from river Kshipra.

anchor.surface_text: It was also the case of the prosecution that divers were employed to. explore the bottom of the river Kshipra near that place from where the other parts of the gun were recovered and a number of disjointed and. mutilated firearm parts, some used and unused cartridges were recovered.

facts.text: Saddle missing one stirrup recovered from house of Darvesh, maternal uncle of Sohrab; strap matched scene strap.

anchor.surface_text: A saddle from which one of the stirrups with a part of the strap was missing was recovered from the house of one, Darvesh, the maternal uncle of accused Sohrab. The strap which is alleged to have been found near the scene of the occcurrence according to the prosecution case,, matched with the stirrup and strap found on that saddle.

facts.text: Autopsy: Sobal Singh died of internal haemorrhage and shock from gunshot wounds to liver, spleen, lungs.

anchor.surface_text: Autopsy,on Sobal singhs body showed that he had died of internal haemorrhage and shock resulting, from gunshot wounds and injuries to vital parts like liver- spleen and lungs-

facts.text: Nadar operated twice, five bullets extracted (three left hand, two right); identified as gun shots.

anchor.surface_text: Accused Nadar was twice operated an and- five bullets were extracted, throe from the left hand and two from the right. These pellets were identified to be gun shots.

facts.text: Ballistic expert: hole in shirt caused by 0.38 revolver; shots from body were gun pellets, not revolver bullets.

anchor.surface_text: The ballistic experts who I also examined several articles, said to have been recovered at the instance of the accused Sohrab were sought to be pieced. The shirt which was recovered from the scene of the, incident which had a hole, was examined by the expert who was of the opinion that that hole companyld only be caused by o.38 revolver. The shots recovered from the body of the deceased were found to be gun shots and number revolver bullets.

facts.text: Sessions Judge disbelieved prosecution witnesses: Madhosingh PW1, Arjun PW2, Kishandas PW6, Babulal PW31.

anchor.surface_text: The evidences of Madhosingh P.W. 1, the father of the deceased and the other witnesses Arjun W. 2, Kishandas P.W. 6, Babulal P.W. 31 were disbelieved.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated August 5, 1969 in Criminal Appeal No. 26 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 5, 1969 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 26 of 1967.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave: Criminal Appeal No. 240 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 240 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 5, 1969

facts.text: High Court discarded pistol firing story as myth, no corroboration.

anchor.surface_text: As regards firing of a pistol, there is absolutely numbercorroboration and the evidence was characterised as a myth.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirmed High Court: Sohrab fired fatal gun shot handed by Nadar; both guilty under 302/34.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we companyfirm the judgment of the High Court and dismiss the appeal.

facts.text: Accused denied guilt; claimed no such incident, death not caused by them.

anchor.surface_text: All the accused denied that guilt and in so far as the appellants are companycerned with whose case alone we are companycerned in their statement under Section 342, they do number say that numbersuch incident took place but that the death of Sobalsingh was number caused by them.

facts.text: FIR lodged by Madhosingh within hour, detailed main story.

anchor.surface_text: Within an hour of the incident, an F.I.R. was lodged in which the main story as spoken to by the witness was given.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, confirmed convictions.

issues.text: Whether in an appeal against acquittal under Sections 417, 418 and 423 CrPC, the High Court has full power to review the evidence at large and reverse the acquittal after considering the trial court's reasons, presumption of innocence and benefit of doubt

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that in an appeal against acquittal, the Appellate Court must consider the reasons which impelled the Trial Court to acquit the accused... High Court has full power to review at large the evidence unon which the order of acquittal was founded and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

issues.text: Whether the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is a sound rule of evidence such that minor contradictions require discarding the entire prosecution testimony

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule for the reason that hardly one comes across a witness whose evidence does not contain a grain of untruth or at any rate exaggeration, embroideries or embellishments.

holdings.text: Sohrab and Nadar are guilty of the offence of murder under Section 302 read with Section 34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: In the above view it was held that both Sohrab and Nadar were guilty of an offence of murder under Section 302 read with 34. We have at some length pointed out that the Sessions Judge and the High Court were in agreement on certain aspects of the case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unanimous eye-witness testimony on Nadar handing gun to Sohrab who fired fatal shots at deceased, corroborated by FIR, medical evidence, recoveries, ballistic report, and accused statements under s342; defence version rejected as inconsistent with evidence; common intention under s34 from concerted actions.

holdings.text: Sohrab and Nadar are guilty under Section 25-A of the Arms Act

anchor.surface_text: , whom he convicted under Section 302/34 and sentenced each of them to life imprisonment. They were also convicted under Section 25-A of the Arms Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed as part of High Court judgment affirming convictions and sentences for unlicensed revolver and gun use/possession, with concurrent rigorous imprisonment.

holdings.text: In an appeal against acquittal under Sections 417, 418 and 423 CrPC, the High Court has full power to review the evidence at large, consider trial court reasons, presumption of innocence, and benefit of doubt, and reverse the acquittal if warranted

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that in an appeal against acquittal, the Appellate Court must consider the reasons which impelled the Trial Court to acquit the accused... High Court has full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Sheo Swarup (PC), Sanwant Singh, Agarwal (SC); High Court weighed trial views, credibility, presumption, doubt but concurred on most points and reversed on core evidence after full review.

holdings.text: The maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule of evidence

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule for the reason that hardly one comes across a witness whose evidence does not contain a grain of untruth or at any rate exaggeration, embroideries or embellishments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witnesses often include exaggeration or embellishment; courts must sift grain of truth from false parts, accepting salient features after scrutiny unless substratum disbelieved.

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court convicting Sohrab and Nadar is confirmed and the appeal is dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we confirm the judgment of the High Court and dismiss the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court findings justified on evidence review; defence inconsistent; prosecution salient features proved beyond doubt.

precedents.citation: Sheo Swarup and Ors. v. King Emperor 1

anchor.surface_text: Sheo Swarup and Ors. v. King Emperor 1  and the judgment of this Court adopting the view enunciated therein have been referred to us.

precedents.case_name: Sheo Swarup and Ors. v. King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court has full power to review evidence in appeal against acquittal and reverse it, but must give proper weight to trial Judge's views on credibility, presumption of innocence, benefit of doubt, and slowness in disturbing findings of fact
precedents.cited_holding: under Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the High Court has full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed. No limitation should be placed upon that power unless it be found expressly stated in the Code. But in exercising the power conferred by the Code and before reaching its conclusions upon fact, the High Court should and will always give proper weight and consideration to such matters as (1) the views of the trial Judge as to the credibility of the witnesses (2) the presumption of innocence in favour of the accused, a presumption certainly not weakened by the fact that he has been acquitted at his trial (3) the right of the accused to the benefit of any doubt and (4) the slowness of an appellate Court in disturbing a finding of fact arrived at by a Judge who had the advantage of seeing the witnesses.

precedents.citation: Sanwant Singh v. State of Rajasthan 2

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that in an appeal against acquittal, the Appellate Court must consider the reasons which impelled the Trial Court to acquit the accused... High Court has full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed.
In this view, we confirm the judgment of the High Court and dismiss the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not a sound rule for the reason that hardly one comes across a witness whose evidence does not contain a grain of untruth or at any rate exaggeration, embroideries or embellishments.
In this view, we confirm the judgment of the High Court and dismiss the appeal.
